text: These days, the world expects always on,
always available services. Remote teams, complex systems,
the increasing need for frequent releases.
It's all created an ever-growing number
of resilience related challenges for organizations.
Well, what is resilience and why does it matter?
Cloud resilience refers to the ability for an application
to resist or recover from disruptions,
including those related to infrastructure,
dependent services, misconfigurations,
and transient network issues.
Since 2008, AWS has been enhancing cloud resilience
through continuous improvements to infrastructure,
service design,
and operational models, while providing customers
with comprehensive tools
and resources. AWS design systems to minimize disruption,
thereby strengthening system, operational,
and organizational resilience, and enhancing your brand
and bottom line. Resilience is a spectrum and
therefore the ideal solution is
different for every organization.
Building your own vetted solution is possible
with guidance from the AWS Solutions
Library. Guidance is a prescriptive technical advice
that provides best practice recommendations on how
to implement the solution needed to meet your use case.
Let's take a closer look at AWS's guidance
for some common resilience use cases. Guidance
for Cross Region Failover
and Graceful Failback on AWS provides advice
for setting up a secure web application with three parts.
A react front end, an AWS Lambda middle tier,
and an Amazon Aurora global database backend.
If there is a disruption
or service impairment in your primary region,
this solution allows your app to quickly switch
to a secondary region, offering continuous service
with minimal disruption.
When the original region is restored, graceful failback
helps you switch back to the primary
region smoothly and easily.
Guidance for Cell-based Architecture on AWS helps create an
architecture that will keep any failure from spreading
and causing problems with the whole application.
This guidance breaks down your services into small pieces,
so if one part has a problem,
the other parts will still work,
and your system can stay stable.
While single region architectures are sufficient
to support most customers' resilience requirements,
a solution for multi-region architectures is ideal
for those with more demanding resilience needs.
Guidance for Multi-Region
Serverless Batch Applications on AWS helps you obtain
insights from your applications
so you can better decide when
to fail over batch applications from a primary
to a standby region.
With curated solutions for resilience from AWS,
your systems can be designed for better protection
and ready to bounce back from unexpected system disruptions.
Find more guidance and solutions
to support your resilient environment in the AWS Solutions
Library.
